meta_data.title: Faith, Not Works, Are the Currency of Salvation
meta_data.subtitle: Galatians 3:11 Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Music by

transcription_data.text: You're listening to the 10-minute Bible Hour podcast. It's fast, fun, free, daily, deep dive Bible. And right now we're talking about Galatians. We're looking at this pivotal moment in the middle of the book of Galatians where Paul, the author of the book of Galatians, is building out his argument. And he's trying to lay the groundwork for why the whole proposition of how the bad guys in the book of Galatians are coming at salvation and right standing for God with God. That is, he's trying to build out the case for why their whole approach is just wrong headed. Their whole approach demonstrates a misunderstanding of the good work of God, then the character of God and the plan of God. And particularly it demonstrates a wrong headed understanding of why God gave the law in the first place, way back in the Old Testament. And to the uncritical reader or on your first pass casually, on my first pass casually, it could look like, oh, Paul's picking a fight here. He's saying there's a fight between the Old Testament God and what God did back there with the law and the New Testament God and what God is doing now through the work of Christ and the cross and with the Holy Spirit. But a closer look reveals, no, he's not setting these two things against each other. What he's saying here is, and this is an analogy we haven't used yet in our conversation on Galatians, but it's one that I like to use a lot when we're talking about Jesus and the book of Matthew and the kingdom and stuff. It's a question of currency. So one time a while back, I went on a trip to Europe and I had some huge Euro note left over. Why I had it? And usually I want to cash that stuff out because it's valuable. But let me tell you what, it's not valuable here where I live in South Dakota. Nobody cares about your stupid euros. So the big giant thing, euros, they just been in my pocket from jeans. I probably sometimes wear jeans a few too many days in a row and I still had my jeans from the trip a couple days earlier on. I sell these euros in my pocket. Somebody's credit card machine was down at a place where I had ordered some food and it was like 10 bucks, but I had like a hundred bucks a euros or something crazy like that. I knew it was a long shot. I didn't have any USD. And so I asked these nice people, these local business owners who are wonderful. Like, can I give you this? Do you ever travel or would your bank swap it later? It's worth so much more than what the cost of this actual little quick lunch was, but your credit card machine's not working. I don't have any cash. This seems like maybe a good compromise. And they were so nice about it. They're like, no, hard pass. No, we don't want to your communist European money. That's their words, not mine. And it's a paraphrase of their words, not mine nor their actual words. They didn't actually in tone anything like that. They just didn't want European money. They didn't care how much European money it was. They didn't care. There was like a five to one or 10 to one ratio, what they were actually owed. It's a pain in the butt. It has no power here. It has no currency here. It's useless. It's just printed paper. No, we trust you. You come here a lot. Just come back with money later. And I did and everything was fine. The point is a bunch of people might get together and say, this currency is valuable. We say it is. And we all say it with lots of intensity and we have lots of meetings about it. There are publications about it. Many smart people gathered together and discuss it. Yeah, but try taking that crap on the road. If you take it somewhere else, somebody's like, it just, it doesn't matter how obsessed you are with this or how much you all got over it and pursue it. It doesn't matter. And it's just wrong headed to bring that currency out here and act like it's going to do something flashing around and nobody cares about your dumb currency from somewhere else. It doesn't mean anything here. Likewise, I really feel like the heart of the argument that Paul is making here is that we're dealing in two different currencies. The currency of the law is something that buys and sells and trades in something else. It doesn't trade in salvation and ultimate right standing with God. It trades in an ethnic national standing with God and it involves some civil stuff on a larger level and it's some kind of stop gap that points to something that happens later. I'm not getting all the way into the weeds here because it's going to get spelled out more explicitly as we get further into Galatians. Our conversation will take us there. But it seems like Paul's argument is you're trying to buy something with a currency that doesn't work on this or to put it way more simply, salvation, ultimate right standing with God, being a Christian, whatever language you want to use is an exercise in faith. That is the only currency that buys it and the only source of all of that of everything in this economy is God himself. All of the ebb and flow and circulation of this currency and these values in his kingdom are his. He bought and paid for them all. They're all his. His to distribute his to use. He's in charge of everything. All of his judgments are right. The currency of the Old Testament law is doing stuff. There's a faith element involved and it would be nonsensical to say that there is not. If we read a lot more of Paul throughout the New Testament, we see that he's not suggesting that faith didn't exist in the Old Testament. Well, of course it did. I think as we read more Paul as well, we would never get the impression that he believed that there was any possibility or any belief that anyone could truly uphold all of the law. He's aware of the sacrificial system. Why did the sacrificial system exist in the Old Testament? Well, it was to fix stuff that people did wrong. So everybody knew that nobody could really uphold the law and maybe I could be accused of inadvertently straw manning the point here just a little bit over the last few days of our conversation. I haven't meant to. I don't think I am, but the point being this, pretty much nobody was out there credibly saying at any point, I pretty, I think we can pretty much uphold every last bit of the law. And then Paul came along and was like, yeah, but what about Deuteronomy 27, 26? And then they were like, ah, dang it. That's right. That part rather what Paul is doing is I think he's trying to push back and with their own assumptions, that is the agitators who are messing with the Galatians and opposed to the actual gospel, I think he's trying to say like with your own assumptions and your own behavior and with the very law you are advocating for all of your actions and all of your words indicate that you know it's the wrong currency for ultimately having right standing with God. It isn't the ultimate and complete solution to the problem of sin, depravity and the failure of humankind and the human problem in general. If it were, why hasn't it worked yet? And Paul goes so far as to use the language that the law comes with a curse. What is that curse? Well, big part of the curse is that it isn't faith. So it might be really valuable in another context. If you're listening to Europe, you can just flip these if you want to. But if you're listening to the United States, it might be that euros are super valuable somewhere else. They just don't do a lot of stuff here. And obviously that metaphor breaks down because there's such a thing as currency exchanges and everything. But I think you understand what I'm driving at point being Paul is making a very nuanced argument with inside baseball using insider language with a whole bunch of people who are deep in the weeds with him in the whole history of the law and all of that. But the thrust of what he's saying is, guys, look at everything you say and believe in what the law itself says, your proposal for how to have right standing with God is wrong headed from the start. You're coming at it wrong. You're trading in the wrong currency. This thing here is entirely a faith currency. You must trade in that currency. That's the only thing that buys anything in this kingdom, in this realm. And it's all owned by God. I don't think Paul is washing his hands of everybody who was on earth before Jesus. I don't think Paul is saying that there was no forgiveness or no squaring up accounts with God. I don't think Paul is washing his hands of all of the work of God with his people in the past. I think he's using very nuanced, very insider language to say, you're coming at this. The wrong way, guys, the righteous will live by faith. Life is the thing we're talking about. Faith is the currency of such a pursuit. And it's been that way since forever. And so of all things, he grabs a quote from Habakkuk to and verse four, we're talking about the Chaldeans or I mean, it's the Chaldeans just means the Babylonians, the people who were going to come a few years after Habakkuk was written and conquer the Jewish people, destroy the temple under Nebuchadnezzar. And there's a dialogue as we talked about yesterday going on between Habakkuk is kind of indignant about how God's coming at this. And God who is pretty comfortable in his own skin and more than content to answer Habakkuk's questions and Habakkuk's second question to God is why are you using people who are even worse than the people of Judah to punish the people of Judah? They're awful. And God's answer is more or less, yeah, yeah, they're bad. They'll get theirs. And I'm going to do what I'm going to do to make the point that I'm going to make, give it time. What a massive paraphrase of something much more beautiful and complex than what I just said. Go read Habakkuk. It's only three chapters. You'll understand it better if you just see what's in there in the first place. But in the midst of this, we're talking about the Chaldeans. And it says, see, he is puffed up. His desires are not upright, but the righteous will live by faith. And it goes on, indeed, wine betrays him. He's arrogant to never at rest because he's as greedy as the grave and like death is never satisfied. He gathers to himself all the nations and takes captive all the people. It's an interesting side note. A lot of this language right here is very similar to some of the language that later Herodotus, the Greek historian, would latch onto and put in the words, put in the mouths, rather, of some of the enemies who stood up to Persia and defied them a little bit later on. I think it's one of the reasons I think maybe Herodotus had a little bit of awareness of Hebrew scripture because I see hints of this language in him. The point is this. Herodotus is saying to Habakkuk, yeah, I mean, the Chaldeans are a mess, but pat on the head, hey, the righteous will live by faith. My guess would be that that was a phrase that was of great consolation to the people while they were in exile. I bet that phrase got repeated a whole lot. But it's one of the five or 10 things from the pre-exile part of the Old Testament that the exiles in captivity in Babylon and Persia would tell themselves, like, hey, we might not have the most stuff right now. We might not be in the best moment. And it might seem like our captors are just living it up and drunk and having fun and all the possessions and all the power, but the righteous will live by faith. It's a beautiful little aside of consolation right there. And I wonder if Paul is harkening back to something that carried even extra meaning here for the people he was interacting with and maybe some of that significance of that phrase or just the commonality of the use of that phrase as a reassurance is maybe passed into history for you and me, whether that's how it was employed or not. He picked that phrase from the Old Testament. The Old Testament is Bible. It's fair game and it's right out of the mouth of God. I mean, maybe that's a big reason that he latched onto it is it's straight from the mouth of God. The righteous will live by faith. God himself in the midst of difficult times saying there's the currency. There's the thing. So look, Galatians chapter three, it's intense. I mean, this is intense language. This is a three way conversation. Two parties in the conversation who are at odds are a former Jewish guy or one, a guy who's the Jew of Jews, ultra trained in all of this in a follower of Christ and others who are maybe masquerading as Christians or not fully Christians or maybe Christians who just totally don't get it. I don't know, they're agitators, but they're rooted in the Old Testament and Judaism as well. And then this poor third party or the people who were getting pulled back and forth and they received the right message before, but then they got tricked and they kind of fell for it. Now they're embarrassed, but they want to get it right. And this is hard. And I'm just reading Paul's letter and we're going to try to get it right from here on out. Bottom line in the midst of this very challenging stuff. And remember Peter himself in one of his letters says Paul's stuff can be really challenging. It's hard. It can be difficult to understand. That's more or less how he says it. This is challenging stuff, but at the heart of it, I think very clearly is Paul saying it is fundamentally wrong headed to imagine that right standing with God is ultimately a product of the currency of doing. Right standing with God is ultimately rather a product of the currency of faith. The righteous will live by faith. Guys, God said so himself, the righteous will live by faith. Now this next chunk, we're going to have to take a handful of verses at once because we just can't break it down verse by verse or it'll become too confusing. And that's what we'll do next time around. All right. It's plenty for now. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt. I'm Matt.
